This may be a little bit simplistic, but I think the ping-pong ball should rise.

In both cases a buoyant force is being exerted on the ball, and by Newton's third law this force is exerted onto the water as well. This force is equal in both jugs because the amount of water displaced is the same. Therefore the buoyant force doesn't matter.

The amount of water in the beakers in both cases is the same, so the weight of the water is irrelevant. 

However, the ping pong ball has a force of tension (from the string) "lifting" the beaker up. This force of tension is equal to the buoyant force minus the weight of the ping pong ball. Because the ping pong ball is buoyant, the buoyant force is greater than the weight of the ping pong ball, and so the force of tension is greater than zero. This will decrease the normal force between the beaker and balance. On the acrylic side the force of tension is acting on the acrylic and the retort stand, but not on the actual beaker or water, and so is not transmitted to the balance. 

Therefore, because the normal force between beaker and balance on the ping-pong ball side is less, the ping-pong ball should rise and the acrylic should fall.
